ClassOverview: This class will present an overview of Western Art Music across several centuries and up to the present, with a focus on symphonic, chamber music, opera, and solo repertoire for piano and other instruments. Students will be guided from a historical perspective to develop listening skills and knowledge of musical terminology, in order to be able to relate to music in a more specific and refined way. Classes will involve listening activities, discussions, one concert report, quizzes, and oral presentations.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: This course will aim to help students develop the skills and tools required to understand and study music's role in our world today and in history, across multiple geographies, and through a variety of genres, styles, and mediums, including both popular music and Western art music.   Focusing on its various social, political, and cultural impacts, we will explore the relationship that we, as individuals and as a society, have with music.  Assignments will range from listening journals and quizzes to concert attendance, along with one final short paper.
School: Bienen School of Music

Class: 175-0 Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
ClassOverview: This course will explore women's musical roles in Western society from the early 16th century to the present. The class is designed to introduce students to a variety of musical genres and to women's participation within a broad range of specific musical cultures. We will consider specifics of women's musical lives, such as performance, composition, and education, alongside changing constructs of femininity. Students will be evaluated through a combination of synchronous and asynchronous online work including reading, discussion, listening assignments, reflections, and a final project.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Women and Music - Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

Class: 175-0 Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
ClassOverview: What is &#39classical music'? How did the concept(s) of classical music develop in Europe and elsewhere over the last few centuries? What roles does this music play in society today? How does &#39classical music&#39 relate to &#39other&#39 musics? These questions will underpin an exploration of the values, processes, historical views, and present situations of this simultaneously specific yet ill-defined kind of music. This course will feature listening, readings, discussions, and writing, and is open to students with all levels of musical experience.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 2: Considering Classical Music - Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

Class: 175-0 Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
ClassOverview: Present in nearly every 20th-century popular music genre and found in the homes of people of all backgrounds, the guitar - whether acoustic or electric - is among the most widespread, iconic instruments in the world.  This course considers the guitar, its music, and its cultural symbolism in a variety of contexts, exploring what the instrument has meant, and continues to mean, to those who have played and heard it throughout history and around the world.  Students will learn about guitar cultures spanning from the Renaissance to the digital age - highlighting performers such as Beethoven-contemporary Mauro Giuliani and blues legend B.B. King - with a particular focus on the 20th century onward, including representations in film, advertising, and video games.  Assignments include topical quizzes, short response papers, and in-class presentation and discussion sections. No previous musical training is required.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 3: History of the Guitar - Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

ClassOverview: This course is intended to communicate the vocabulary and elements of Western common-practice tonal music and its place in the broader cultural milieu. Contextualized through engagement with historical and contemporary Western and non-Western music and thought, the class will explore musical concepts such as rhythm, sound, and melodic construction in their relation to harmony, with the goal of developing an understanding that will enrich student's musical experiences. This class is intended for non-music majors and music minors.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: The fall-quarter Keyboard Skills course for piano majors expands reading skills with a focus on two genres, string quartet and four-part vocal score.  String quartet score reading prepares students for scores larger than the traditional two-staves piano score.  The vocal or SATB score develops flexibility and provides skills for working with choirs.  Harmonizing melodies or composing mini-pieces will synthesize the proper realization of chord symbols with creative application of patterns.  A project involving a guided approach to sight-reading along with recognition of the integral role of changing rhythmic values in a piece will span several weeks in the form of a sight-reading journal.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: The termclassical musicis used in many different ways. One commonly recurring notion is that it may be understood as acanon? a select group of composers and compositions which, through their timeless value and universality, set the standard for artistic accomplishment in the art of music. A closer examination, however, reveals all kinds of difficulties with this simple notion. Before 1800, nearly all performances presented exclusively contemporary music, and works more than about fifty years old were considered hopelessly outmoded. This changed over the course of the nineteenth century as European musicians, audiences, and publishers set about identifying certain composers - originally Bach, Handel, Mozart, and Beethoven, but subsequently also Schubert, Chopin, Schumann, Brahms, Wagner, Verdi, etc. - and valorizing their contributions with lavish biographies, marble busts, and complete-works editions. But isclassical musictruly universal? Are there identifiable, qualitative musical differences between music in the canon and other works which have not entered the repertoire? To what extent canon-formation by factors such as nationalism, racism, and gender bias? This course seeks to both introduce a variety of extremely famousclassicalworks and to interrogate the processes that made them famous.
MeetingInfo: Regenstein Hall of Music MCR: Tues, Thurs, 9:30AM - 10:50AM
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: The Levels 4, 5, 6 course sequence is required for but not limited to Music Education majors. Level 4 provides students of intermediate level with a range of keyboard skills emphasizing accompanying skills, interactive musicianship, and advanced keyboard theory. Other topics include secondary dominants, reducing techniques with regular or accompaniment sight reading, ensemble skills, two-handed accompaniments from existing harmonizations, and individual repertoire choices. The final accompaniment project provides students opportunities to work with another musician and share musical thoughts.
Instructor: Karen Chih-Pah Kan-Walsh| Annie Chia-Chien Hsiao|
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: The Levels 7, 8, 9 course sequence is required for but not limited to Choral Music Education majors.  Level 7 course materials focus on vocal scores, in accessible keys, in the SATB format.  Students will develop strategies for learning a score as is in addition to individual methods of reducing the texture.  Students will sight read literature with varying amounts of preparation (2 minutes, 1 day, or several days).  These experiences will serve to identify areas that require concrete, practical strategies to strengthen weak skills that will eventually become important resources in the student's development of their vocal- and choral-pedagogical identity.  Technical work will build on previous piano experience with an emphasis on healthful, fluent playing.  The Mini-Recital near the end of the quarter brings class members together in an informal sharing of solo piano repertoire which has been studied and coached for the entire quarter.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: The Alexander Technique (AT) class serves as an introduction to the AT while practicing ways of applying the principles of the AT to everyday activities, practicing, performing, performance anxiety, and stress management. This class is a hands-on learning experience. See: www.amsatonline.org and www.alexandertechnique.co.uk for a description of the AT.

This class is a hands-on learning experience. See: www.amsatonline.org and www.alexandertechnique.co.uk for a description of the AT.
School: Bienen School of Music

Class: 360-0 Career Innovation in Music and the Performing Arts
ClassOverview: Today's successful musician must embody entrepreneurship in career-making alongside the artistry of music-making. Students who enroll in this course will learn about various career models in music and the performing arts. Besides covering basic knowledge about conventional career paths, this course will facilitate and encourage students to imagine how they might innovate such conventions, taking advantage of the fast-changing environment of professional musicians in today's dynamic culture. Specific practical skills relevant to performing-arts careers will be complemented by open-ended exploration of what it means – and could mean – to be a performing artist. In the final analysis, the course will prepare students to begin work on building a career with the same discipline and creativity they apply every day to their musicianship.This course is a hybrid seminar-practicum. Class discussions will drive thinking about unconventional performing-arts careers while team-based work on projects will develop practical skills necessary for launching an innovative arts venture. In the process, students will gain an understanding of how the performing-arts field operates so that you can take professional advantage of a variety of opportunities and create opportunities for yourself and others. Guest speakers representing various career types and innovations will also familiarize students with basic know-how to offer current models of effective change.Along the way, the course will cover skills and topics that affect all performing-arts related careers, drawn from business-related fields including: fee and contract negotiation; artist and booking management; fundraising and grant-writing; communication, marketing and public relations; social media; organizational and business structures; intellectual property rights; business model generation; arts advocacy; diversity, equity and inclusion; and community engagement.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Career Innovation in Music and the Performing Arts

ClassOverview: As an introduction to the basic tools of resources in music research, the class includes study of general library resources, bibliographies of composers, music, music literature, and music sources. Students will experience a broad view of music reference tools and editions of music. Key projects in the class are providing an appropriate bibliography for a selected research topic, and selecting an appropriate performing edition for practical use based on a variety of sources.

ClassOverview: Doctoral Music Research combines a survey of resources used most commonly in music research with an introduction to approaches for evaluating and expressing ideas about music. The knowledge and skills developed in this course provide students in the Doctor of Musical Arts and Ph.D. in Composition programs with fundamental abilities in research and written expression that can be applied and built upon in other coursework, as well as throughout a career in music.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: An examination of the roles of women in rock music from the inception of the genre through today, framed by changing social expectations for women and increasing acceptance of diversity among performers, audiences, and consumers. Students will read scholarship in music, gender theory, and social sciences, and will conduct research in physical and online archives as well as engage critically with music, video, and film.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Women Rock - Topics in Popular Music

ClassOverview: This course will examine the role of race in a select group of operas from the 18th C through the present.   The course will be articulated in three principal categories:1) the dramatic and musical depiction of non-Europeans in works such as Rameau'sLes Indes Galantes, Mozart'sDie Zauberflöte, Verdi'sIl Corsaro,Un Ballo in Maschera,La Forza del Destino,Aida, andOtello, and Puccini'sMadama Butterfly,La Fanciulla del West, andTurandot2) racial issues relating to performance, not only with regard to works such as those listed above, but to the operatic repertoire in general, such as the use of makeup (race as a &#39costume') and non-traditional or &#39colorblind&#39 casting
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: What does music have to do with death, dying, and traditional beliefs regarding the afterlife?  In what ways can music confront, express, or provide consolation for these experiences?  In what ways can music confront, express, or provide consolation for these experiences?  This course will cut across historical periods as well as boundaries of genre to explore the musical response to death in both instrumental and vocal works chosen a wide chronological range. Units of the course will include the Requiem Masses of Berlioz, Verdi, Dvořák, Fauré, and others; the frequent use of the GregorianDies Iraemelody as a musical symbol; selected death scenes in opera; visions of the afterlife in both vocal and orchestral music; and examples drawn from the genres of elegy, dirge, and in memoriam.Each student is expected to complete two written assignments (worth 20 pts. each if submitted on time, half credit if submitted late but within one week of the due date), two 5-minute PowerPoint presentations (or equivalent technology), chosen by the students (20 pts. each) on topics approved by the instructor, and a take-home Final Examination (20 points).  Graduate students have the option of undertaking a research project in lieu of the Final Exam, with the final paper being due on the same day that the Exam is due for submission.   There will be no midterm in the course.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: No music is performed more frequently at the Bienen School than that of J. S. Bach. A recent survey of student recital programs over a five-year period found that works by Bach were performed a total of 267 times, considerably more than works by his closest competitors: Brahms (160), Mozart (155), Beethoven (145), Schubert (133) and Robert Schumann (110). Bach is also one of the most intensively studied musicians of the past two hundred years. This course serves as an introduction to recent research. We begin with a survey of the composer's biography followed by close readings of influential articles and books, and analysis of his music.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: J.S. Bach, An Introduction - Composer Topics

ClassOverview: This course will focus on the centrality of Venice - and the musical styles that disseminated from Venice - to the history of seventeenth-century European music. We will navigate the unique topography of Venice to interrogate why musical styles such as monody, polychoral church music, and commercial opera developed and flourished there; how printing and commerce drove musical style and practices; how popular and elite music intersected; and how music interacts with the verbal, architectural, and visual arts. Much of the course focuses on music by Giovanni Gabrieli, Claudio Monteverdi, Barbara Strozzi, and Francesco Cavalli, but it also considers Venetian styles in diaspora in the works of Heinrich Schütz (Saxony), Marcin Mielczewski (Poland), Juan Gutiérrez de Padilla (Mexico), and others. Students will tackle articles from scholarly journals, monographs, and primary sources; engage the concept of baroque within the frame of cultural studies; and debate the social functions of vocal music. We will also look at selected seventeenth-century repertoires un-related to Venice in order for students to feel confident with their understanding of the period in general.The course is aimed at students with some previous background in baroque music and will be conducted as a mixture of lectures, discussion, and student research presentations. Italian and/or Latin language skills are useful but not required.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Venetian Music - Topics in 17th Century Music

ClassOverview: This course is intended to help students in all music academic fields, composition, and performance think about the role of editors, editions, performers, and performance in presenting music in all media, including digitized formats. We will consider original musical works in score and recorded formats, and the processes surrounding ways in which they've been modified over time for different performers, performances, and audiences as well as presented as the original creators knew them. Each student will create an original edition of a chosen work or linked set of works, using editorial methods covered in the course, and we will consider histories and purposes of notation and other technologies for presenting music; composition students may develop original notation if they so choose. Scholarly material and methodologies will be drawn from all fields of musical inquiry, from critical theory, from textual histories and cultures, and from the digital humanities. If conditions permit, we will visit the University Archives and Newberry Library to look at original, unedited music and to consider historical recording and playback technologies.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: This course is designed as an introduction to the field of music education. It will provide you with an overview of the multifaceted nature of K-12 music teaching and learning and serve as a foundation for the construction of your own beliefs and practices as a teacher. We will observe music classrooms as well as read about and discuss a variety of current issues and exciting movements in music education.

Class: 423-0 Paradigms and Processes of Research in Music Teaching and Learning
ClassOverview: An introductory graduate course that explores fundamentals of designing and implementing research that focuses on human participants. We will consider the basics of quantitative and qualitative approaches to inquiry, explore the development of compelling research questions, and develop strategies to evaluate published studies. A helpful first step for graduate students considering topics, projects, or theses that focus on musical behavior.

ClassOverview: Exploration of processes related to the acquisition and development of music skills. Particular attention will be given to music teaching processes and how music learning may be mediated by formal and informal contexts. The course will utilize a seminar format in which students will explore and discuss current research and applications to teaching and learning practice. Appropriate for graduate students in any area of music interested in or engaged with music teaching.

ClassOverview: This course is designed to provide an introduction for students of any musical background to the tools, techniques, and concerns involved in a musical composition process. Students will be responsible for realizing their compositions either by performing the work themselves, recruiting friends/collaborators, or through video/audio recordings.Students are required to come to class with an open mindset as well as a willingness to share their work in order to encourage in-class listening and discussion. Previous knowledge of music creation and/or music theory is not required, but because of the hands-on nature of the class, proficiency on a musical instrument (including voice) or a DAW is required.Class sessions will include discussions of assigned listening and reading, creative activities, short presentations, and workshopping of your peers' compositions. Weekly small projects will culminate in a more substantial final creative work.

ClassOverview: The essential aim of the three-quarter orchestration sequence is to develop a practical familiarity with all of the standard orchestral instruments (and perhaps a sampling of the non-standard ones...). Topics to be addressed during the sequence will include: families of instruments, individual ranges and transpositions, idiomatic technical considerations, timbral parameters and their relationship to dynamics, transcription techniques, spatialization, texture, and extended techniques. Orchestration will be approached from a variety of perspectives: practical, historical, and structural.Although each quarter will be taught by a different member of the composition faculty, the courses are intended to be taken in sequence. Therefore 314-1 is a prerequisite to taking 314-2, and both are prerequisites to taking 314-3 in the spring.During the first quarter, we will focus primarily on the characteristics of solo instruments belonging to one or another instrumental choir. Combinations of instrumental forces will follow later in the sequence, in winter and spring quarters. Coursework will take the form of readings from the text, critical listening, score study/analysis, writing projects, and short quizzes. These quizzes will pertain to subjects such as notational issues, instrumental ranges, definition of terms (Italian, French, German, English), transposition, et cetera. Sometimes they will be announced ahead of time. In addition to the textbook, you will need a reliable means of notation, parameters of which will be discussed at the outset of the course.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: The class will undertake a survey of 20th and 21st century operas with a special focus on works with innovative positions towards the relation of music (voice) and narrative. After a brief analysis of the point of departure (Wagner'sTristan, Berg'sWozzeck) we will discuss works that have radically challenged the traditional understanding of opera: Phillip Glass'Einstein On the Beach, Morton Feldman's?Neither, Chaya Czernowin'sPnima, Helmut Lachenmann'sMädchen mit den Schwefelhölzernas well as works by Salvatore Sciarrino, Liza Lim, and David T. Little. Furthermore, we will look at tendencies in contemporary theater and dance, (Wilson, Wooster Group, Forsythe, Bausch) and discuss aesthetic concepts that influence contemporary opera composition. An important part of the class will be a creative workshop: the students will work on drafting an opera project.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Voice vs. Narrative - Contemporary Opera - Topics in Contemporary Repertoire

ClassOverview: This course examines how musicians organize to create artistic communities and opportunities outside of various institutional structures. We will discuss notable organizations/collectives that have forged unique artistic and social paths, such as Bang On A Can, the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians (AACM), Wandelweiser, and New Discipline, among others. In addition to addressing some of the socio-economic and political profiles each of these groups embody, we will discuss and analyze the music and broader aesthetic profiles of each group as well. While much of the course will focus on engaging with these groups historically, we will also discuss potential strategies to enact in the present and future.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: DIY Musical Communities - Compositional Concepts and Techniques

Class: 355-2 History and Analysis of Electroacoustic Music
ClassOverview: The class will explore critical approaches to digital art music (1960s to the present), emphasizing historical and aesthetic context, as well as reverse engineering strategies.  Analytical models will draw from a series of computer works by Xenakis, Chowning, Smalley, Truax, Koonce, and others.  Topics covered include digitalmusique concrete, algorithmic composition, and spectralism.  Assignments consist of analytical papers and presentations.

Section: 1: History and Analysis of Electroacoustic Music

ClassOverview: Contrapuntal textures from two to four voices. Cadence and form, melodic line and motive, rhythm, simple and complex imitation, and treatment of dissonance in the sacred music of Palestrina, Victoria, Lassus, and Josquin.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: German Romantic song (Lied) takes a special place in the repertoire of Western art music. Born from the spirit of Romanticism, it epitomizes the aesthetics of this artistic movement by its deep bond between music and poetry and intimate collaboration of voice and accompaniment. In this course we will trace the development of German Romantic song from its origins in Schubert, through its further development by Schumann and Brahms, until its late incarnations in orchestral songs by Mahler and Richard Strauss. Underway, we will learn the German poets whose texts were most frequently set to music (Goethe, Müller, Heine, Eichendorff, Rückert), explore issues of poetic rhythm, meter, and versification, and investigate their relation to musical rhythm, meter and form. We will excavate meaning and expression of individual songs as it emerges from the interaction between music and poetry and from interrelation of individual songs within song cycles.The course will be of interest for students of music theory, musicology as well as vocal and instrumental performance.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Romantic Song - Selected Topics in Music Theory

ClassOverview: This course is a review of tonal music theory that is the basis of more advanced study. Through analysis, part-writing, melody harmonization, and figured-bass realization, we will explore the diatonic foundations of tonality, and trace how composers extended diatonic harmony to create chromatic resources during the 19th century.By the end of the course, you should be able to harmonize melodies and realize figured bass in four-part chorale style; construct and analyze harmonies; and identify some basic aspects of musical form.
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: A deep and critical examination of the epistemological, philosophical, and sociological foundations of music research and the question of truth.

ClassOverview: This class engages Brahms' late piano works (Opp. 116-119) both for their own sake structurally and aesthetically and as a vehicle for understanding the analysis of 19th century chromatic music.    The primary theoretical frameworks will be those proposed by Daniel Harrison and Fred Lerdahl.    The class will fulfill both the DM writing requirement for students who need classes of that kind in their curriculum, and the theory examination waiver requirement.
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 2: Late Piano Music Brahms - Selected Topics in Music Theory

ClassOverview: Expectation is an aspect of listening experience that has attracted lots of attention from music theorists since the second half of the twentieth century. After the pioneering work of Leonard B. Meyer and his students, Eugene Narmour and Robert O. Gjerdingen, further research of musical expectation was undertaken by scholars working in the field of cognitive study of music, generating an ever-growing number of influential publications. In this seminar we will reconstruct this stream of research from its dawn until today and try to assess its prospects. To this end, we will retrace the questions that have been asked by earlier authors and appraise the answers that have been given. The questions will include: What is expectation? How does it arise? How does it inform musical meaning and emotion? What musical parameters does it concern? Is it determined by structure of these parameters? Or is it a matter of statistics? What types of knowledge does it engage? How does it relate to consciousness and memory?
School: Bienen School of Music
Section: 1: Musical Expectation - Seminar in Music Theory & Cognition

ClassOverview: Goals of the course: 1. Develop more systematic ways of thinking about music cognition. 2. Become familiar with important issues, investigative techniques, and literature in music cognition. 3. Know the basics of cognitive psychology. 4. Be able to read a psychological article on music from a standard journal and understand it reasonably well. 5. Know the main journals and texts in which one is likely to find materials of interest to students of music cognition.Structure of the course: 1. Unit I (one wk): Basics of cognitive psychology and auditory perception 2. Unit II (three wks): The structure of music and music cognition 3. Unit III (two wks): Musical, emotion, and memory 4. Unit IV (one wk): Music and the body 5. Unit IV (one wk): Musical performance 6. Unit V (one wk): Creativity and music's relation to other domains
School: Bienen School of Music

ClassOverview: Baroque Performance Practice: This course will be a brief overview of historical performance sources and repertoire from roughly 1600-1750. Participants will explore solo and ensemble music outside the canon of common repertoire while studying playing techniques and sound aesthetics of the 17th and 18th centuries. All instrumentalists are welcome to participate. Grading will be based on class participation, brief written assignments, and final in-class performance of a short solo work.Recommended text: Performing Baroque Music by Mary Cyr, Amadeus Press 1992.

ClassOverview: This class focuses on the allocation of authority between business owners and decision-makers, with special attention to fiduciary duties.  It draws on statutory and case law, including Delaware's statute, in recognition of its influence. Corporate law is emphasized but included are agency, partnership, limited liability companies and public benefit companies.In addition, students will learn about the work of transactional lawyers who represent business clients through an interview project.This section takes students through a wide range of issues related to the law governing business organizations, from forming a business, to sharing and distributing profits, to the duties of those who manage the business and what happens when they have a conflict with the owners about the direction of the business.  Problems are used, particularly to learn about the statutory material.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: This course is designed to acquaint students with the law of unincorporated business associations (such as partnerships and limited liability companies) and corporations. The course will include discussions of the law and its implications for business associations today, with some policy analysis. The focus of this section is practical rather than theoretical, with special attention to the lawyer's role in transactional planning and the application of legal doctrine in practice.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: Coverage of all of the fundamentals of securities regulation at the US federal law, for private and publicly held companies and their shareholders/investors -- limited to Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Class: 633U Venture Capital and Early Stage Financing
ClassOverview: This class will provide students with an introduction to venture capital and other early stage financing transactions within start-up and growth businesses.  Topics that are expected to be covered include the demand for risk capital, the various types of financing available to start-up companies, the most common structures used in these deals, the process by which a financing round is negotiated and consummated, best practices for founders in making an initial pitch to a potential venture capital investor, a survey of the the material terms contained within venture capital term sheets and the principal investment documents (including the ways in which these terms are being negotiated between founders and investors in the current market), exits and initial public offerings in venture capital-backed businesses, a review of certain portions of typical venture capital financing documentation (including preferred stock purchase agreements, certificates of incorporation, investors' rights agreements, right of first refusal and co-sale agreements and voting agreements), and financing closings.  We will also regularly discuss current trends within and related to the venture capital space.  Relevant legal considerations will be examined, but the emphasis will be on the practical and market considerations involved in these deals.
Instructor: Darren M Green| Esther S Barron|
School: Law School
Section: 1: Venture Capital and Early Stage Financing

ClassOverview: Banks perform a unique role in the economic sphere and, unlike most other private enterprises, are subject to extensive regulation and supervision. In addition to lectures and discussions, half of the classes will involve practical simulations, including negotiating an M&A transaction. The course does not focus on the many technical regulations governing the financial industry, but emphasizes the rationales driving oversight of regulations and policies.
Instructor: John E Freechack| Robert M Fleetwood|
School: Law School

ClassOverview: The course is intended to provide students with the basic tools required for an entry level mergers and acquisitions practice, which includes a mix of statutory and doctrinal principles, with particular emphasis on the duties and and responsibilities of Boards of Directors, introduction to the more common forms of transactions (focusing primarily on mergers and asset acquisitions), exposure to deal process, dynamics and tactics, including, among other things, friendly and hostile transactions, tender offer mechanics and proxy contests.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: Contact the department for further information
School: Law School

ClassOverview: 1.	A primary objective is to master antitrust analysis. This mastery requires a basic understanding of price theory in economics as well as the major cases decided under the Sherman and Clayton Acts.2.	Another primary objective is to understand business behavior. One cannot be a good antitrust lawyer without a sense of what matters to business success and productivity and why businesses engage in the practices they do. Thus, discussion in this course is designed to help stimulate a better entrepreneurial imagination and sympathy.3.	A secondary objective of the course is to increase the student's facility with law and economics generally so that students can deploy this method in other areas of law. To that end, some economic concepts will be introduced, like Ronald Coase's theory of the firm.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: Modern government is administrative government. This course concerns the legal institutions and the procedures that administrative government uses in promulgating and enforcing regulations as well as the procedures that private parties interacting with the government use to protect themselves.  We will learn a good deal of legal doctrine about the general principles that limit agency power and discretion.  The overall goal is to equip students to represent the interests of their clients before agencies. That means understanding what an agency is, how it works, and what procedural and substantive levers are available to influence its decisions. Since the substance of regulation subtly affect how courts view procedure, the course also touches on the basics of regulatory policy.
MeetingInfo: Levy-Mayer 204 Booth Hall: Mon, Tues, Wed, 10:55AM - 11:50AM
School: Law School

ClassOverview: Contact the department for further information

School: Law School

ClassOverview: This course examines the work of lawyers representing low-income clients in civil cases and engaging in other civil public interest legal work through experiential and in-class learning. The course will explore practical and ethical issues faced by public interest lawyers and the challenges of enforcing legal rights of low-income clients. In addition to the weekly seminar, students spend 12 hours per week in an approved externship with a non-profit public interest organization doing civil legal work. Students work under the supervision of attorneys in these offices and conduct research, write briefs and memoranda, interview clients and witnesses, participate in community education efforts, and assist attorneys in trial preparation and trial.  Students secure their own placement in consultation with the faculty member.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: The first year of law school is largely about learning to interpret cases. But modern law is increasingly based on statutes, and modern lawyers need a second skillset: the ability to understand and interpret statutes with lawyerly sophistication. This course aims to develop that skillset. Grades will be based on class participation at 40%, final exam at 40%, and in-class presentations at 20%.This course has four learning objectives. Learning objective 1 is to develop an advanced understanding of statutory interpretation. We will examine sweeping theories like purposivism and textualism, interpretive canons like plain meaning and constitutional avoidance, and other aspects of statutory interpretation as a field. Students will join the great debates that fascinate and divide lawyers and judges today. Learning objective 2 is to develop the ability to wield interpretive theory in legal argument. Students will practice crafting arguments from purposivist, textualist, and other standpoints, learning not just the theory of statutory interpretation but the practice as well. Learning objective 3 is to understand how legislation functions in the overall structure of American democracy. Democratic countries make law chiefly through representatives of the people assembled in legislatures; that is the ideal, anyway. Is it the reality? This course will ask fundamental questions about whether the process of making, interpreting, and enforcing legislation in contemporary America corresponds to democratic ideals. Learning objective 4 is to practice engaging respectfully and thoughtfully with ideas opposed to one's own. This course will cover a wide array of ideas, some politically inflected, and it is crucial to the teaching and learning experience that everyone bring a spirit of debate, curiosity about different perspectives, and respect for one another to class discussion.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: In this course students will study the federal judiciary through observation of courtroom proceedings, participation in judicial decision making, and academic examinations of issues facing the judiciary. In addition to the weekly seminar, students work 12 to 15 hours a week in approved externships for federal and select state court judges. Students maintain reflective journals analyzing their field placement experiences and class topics and responding to questions about their externship.  The class offers students opportunities to improve a variety of skills used by lawyers, including research, analysis, writing, listening, and presentation.  Students secure their own externships with the assistance of the professor.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: The colloquium introduces students to Law and Society scholarship. This wide-ranging field, often described as focusing on law in action rather than law on the books, uses empirical research to explore the real world context in which legal rules and decisions emerge and operate. Every second week, a professor from outside the law school will present a paper; on weeks without an outside speaker, we will meet to discuss the paper that will be presented the following week, as well as the assigned background reading, if any.

Students will act as both prosecutors and defense lawyers.The class also covers preparation of witnesses, evidentiary problems, and arguments to the court.The final exam will be a half-day mock trial of a criminal case
Instructor: Matthew M Schneider| Joel R Levin| Daniel William Gillogly| Morris O Pasqual|

ClassOverview: This course will introduce students to the law governing the prosecution and defense of white-collar crime. The course will cover the substantive law in the area such as mail and wire fraud, bribery, insider trading, perjury and obstruction of justice. The course will also provide an overview of typical procedural and practical issues, such as the use of the Grand Jury, Fifth Amendment invocation, internal investigations, parallel civil and criminal proceedings, corporate compliance programs, and sentencing. Finally, the course will put these principles into context with examples from past and recent white collar crime cases, such as the Galleon insider trading cases, the Pharma Bro case, Operation Varsity Blues (college admissions), Fyre Festival, and the Mueller investigations,  and will draw on the instructor's and guest lecturers' experiences as Assistant United States Attorneys, federal judges, and criminal defense lawyers.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: As restorative justice practitioner Kay Pranis suggests, Restorative Justice as a field flows back and forth between practice that informs philosophy and philosophy that informs practice. Class learning will involve opportunities to learn through practice, which is different than most traditional legal education courses. As a class, we will work in partnership to create a restorative learning community that fosters critical thinking, healthy communication, inclusion, engagement, compassion, love, and introspection. Some course topics and issues that arise through the semester will be challenging. The class community will work on collective and self-care, and all students are encouraged to communicate their needs and reach out for additional support.
School: Law School

Class: 601 Jurisprudence: Foundational Questions of Law and Lawyering
ClassOverview: This course gives students an opportunity to ask some of the big questions about law, about politics, and about one's own life in the law. Unit I is about four influential theories of law: legal positivism, natural law, legal realism, and critical legal studies. Unit II is about the nature of democracy. We will examine theories of what democracy is and ask whether contemporary democratic countries live up to democratic ideals. Unit III is about one's own life in the law. We will examine whether the adversarial system does more harm than good and how a lawyer's life can be a life worth living. The three units thus focus, respectively, on legal philosophy, political philosophy, and ethical philosophy, as philosophers use those terms, and the course is indeed highly philosophical. Yet the course is designed so that students do not need prior training in philosophy to take it; the reading material and class discussion are designed to speak to all.What is necessary is a taste for theoretical thinking (this is not a black-letter law course) and an active desire to engage with ideas different from one's own (an open, debating structure in which students are called upon to consider and even voice arguments with which they personally disagree is part of the structure of the course).
School: Law School
Section: 1: Jurisprudence: Foundational Questions of Law and Lawyering

ClassOverview: Advanced Legal Research is a hands-on, experiential course that relies on practice.  Studies on learning show that people do not learn by watching other people research, listening to people talk about research, or reading about research.  You can only learn to research by practicing!  Luckily, most of that practice takes place in class.  If you attend class and give the in-class exercises your best effort, you'll be half of the way to success.  The other half comes from learning from the feedback that you'll receive.  I will give you a lot of feedback on your outside of class assignments.  You will also get a rubric that will tell you what I'm looking for.  As you learn from the feedback and from your experiences in class, you will find yourself becoming a more efficient and confident researcher!
School: Law School

ClassOverview: This is an interactive course, where we try to get a feel for what it's like to be a transactional lawyer and where we focus on getting as much practice drafting as possible. If you have questions about any aspect of the course, please contact me by email at: m-llorente@law.northwestern.edu or schedule a meeting with me at: https:outlook.office365.com/owa/calendar/MonicaLlorente@nuwildcat.onmicrosoft.com/bookings/. I am willing and eager to answer any questions about the course, and I am interested in your feedback and suggestions.

Class: 628 Advanced Legal Writing: Writing for the Court
ClassOverview: This course teaches the core principles of effective writing for judicial law clerks. Through readings, discussion, and writing exercises and critique, students will develop the ability to think and write like an impartial decision-maker. The three graded assignments will entail researching, drafting and editing bench memos and opinions, resulting in one or more writing samples suitable for clerkship and other job applications.
School: Law School
Section: 1: Advanced Legal Writing: Writing for the Court

ClassOverview: This seminar will attempt to answer a perennial question - How can a good lawyer be a good person? - through an examination of attorney memoirs.  We often study legal ethics through the use of hypothetical problems that are intended to raise vexing issues for practicing lawyers.  Even in sophisticated simulations (such as those used at Northwestern), however, it is nearly impossible to duplicate the exigencies, pressures, and conflicting demands experienced by contemporary lawyers.  Studies of the legal profession are also often one step removed (at least) from actual law practice, based on surveys or aggregations of information that do not address the actions of individuals.Lawyer (and judge) memoirs may be the means to bridge this gap, providing an opportunity to explore the ways in which individuals assume roles, make compromises, and seek solutions to daily problems in law firms and in courts.  Of course, most memoirs are self-serving (when they are not self-aggrandizing), so they will have to be read with much skepticism.  But that will be revealing as well, as we will be able to consider the most common rationalizations that are used to excuse -- and sometimes glorify -- questionable choices and conduct.Some memoirists are painfully introspective, some appear to be blinded by ego, and others are surprisingly na?ve.  In combination, I believe this literature can be the basis for some true insights into the way law is, and should be, practiced.

ClassOverview: TEACHING METHODA.	The Simulated CourtroomThis course is taught in the simulated courtroom method.  Each week you will be assigned to perform as trial counsel in one or more advocacy problems.  For the most part these problems will consist of direct and cross examinations.  The witnesses may be played by members of the faculty, but frequently you will be called upon to play the witness (especially in those problems for which you have been assigned a direct examination).Each student will be designated an A or a B for the purposes of the assignments.  Unless you are instructed otherwise, please prepare each assignment according to your A or B designation.  You will retain your designation for the entire semester. At the beginning of each class session court will convene.  From that point onward you are expected to act in the role of trial counsel at all times other than during critique or discussion.B.	The All Object RuleThe law of evidence is a crucial aspect of every trial, and it is essential that you learn both to make and to respond to evidentiary objections.  Accordingly, all students and instructors may make objections at any time during any problem session.  To raise an objection you must stand and state your legal grounds.C.	CritiqueAt various times during each class session the student performances will be critiqued by the faculty.  The purpose of critique is to help you evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of your own performance, with an eye toward future improvement.  Our goal in critique is not to criticize you either as an advocate or a person, but rather to alert you to any mistakes and to make specific and forward-looking suggestions.Please be aware that on a faculty of over 50 trial lawyers there are bound to be diverging points of view -- not to mention outright disputes -- as to how any particular exercise ought to be approached.  Do not be frustrated when you receive contradictory advice from different instructors.  The first step in your own development as a trial lawyer is to analyze such contrasting information and to determine which approach is best for you.

ClassOverview: For most lawyers, negotiation is a critical part of their professional duties.  Of matters that come into a lawyer's office, the vast majority are resolved by negotiation.  Negotiation and communication for the purpose of persuasion are also a major element of everyday life.  This course is designed to give students experience in negotiation, as well as a grounding in negotiation theory.  The emphasis of the course is on experiential learning.  Students spend most of their time participating in negotiation simulations, as well as discussing negotiation problems.  Students are observed in their negotiations and receive feedback.  Several negotiations are recorded for later viewing and feedback.The negotiation simulations cover a wide range of situations.  In past years, students have negotiated the settlement of lawsuits, neighborhood disputes, campus disputes, personal services contracts, contracts for the sale and purchase of commercial and residential property, intra-family disputes, corporate takeovers, international disputes, and labor disputes.This is an experiential learning class that provides opportunities to develop negotiation skills through simulations, pre-negotiation analysis, reflection, and other activities. There are weekly assignments that are designed to explore negotiation concepts and strategies. At the end of the semester, students practice their negotiation skills through working with classmates on a final group project.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: NOTE: All students must be available to attend an all day training on September 18, 2021 as part of this 4 credit course.This a a simulation course focuses on the skills necessary to mediate disputes and advocate for clients in the mediation process.  Students must take this course to be eligible to take the Professor Cohn's Mediation Practicum in the spring. Students who take the practicum will mediate disputes in the Cook County court system through the Center for Conflict Resolution (CCR).Northwestern has partnered with CCR to provide professional mediation skills training during the course of the semester.  CCR is one of the nation's largest and longest running community mediation centers.  It provides extensive mediation services in Chicago through the Cook County court system and community-based referrals (www.ccrchicago.org).  As part of this professional training, all students must attend a mandatory weekend training session on September 18, 2021.Students certified as CCR mediators will be eligible to conduct actual mediations on behalf of CCR in the 4 credit hour mediation practicum during the Spring semester (LITARB 676).  Certification as a CCR mediator is determined by a committee of CCR trainers and is based on a student's ability to successfully complete a series of simulated mediations and demonstrate mastery of CCR's mediation model.  Students interested in pursuing certification must attend the additional training session taking place September 19, September 25, October 2, 2021.In addition to the training held by CCR, students pursuing certification may be required to do other activities and simulations inside and outside of class in order to meet certification requirements. Students are expected to make all reasonable efforts, including but not limited to, finding role players, participating in simulations and role plays, and completing suggested exercises, in order to meet the certification standard by November 15.  Because certification by CCR is a prerequisite to enroll in the Mediation Practicum course, a student must be certified before the end of the fall semester or they will not be eligible to enroll in the spring Mediation Practicum.Once students complete the practicum, they may maintain their certification by continuing to mediate at CCR once a month.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: In this course, we will explore the roles lawyers and other stakeholders play as advocates for social, political, and civic change. Students in this class will engage in real-life and class-based learning. During the semester, students will work with non-lawyers at a community-based or change-oriented organization. Change-oriented means any organization working actively to move the needle on a particular issue or set of issues. Students are free to select an organization that aligns with their interests, but the organization needs to be approved by the professor, so reach out to her as soon as possible. The professor is also willing to help you find an organization that would specifically interest you or allow you to select an organization in need of help that she has available. You should begin looking for an organization prior to the start of the semester, since you should have the organization finalized by the first week of class.Through this course, students will engage in discussions on real-life issues impacting different communities and will have the opportunity to speak with community leaders and advocates who are working to create change in their own communities. Topics to be covered in this course include: organizing and different theories of change, the tools and strategies of lawyers working for change, the history of lawyers working with different movements and communities, and how race, class, and power affect particular movements and your work. There are also weeks when we discuss whatever topics students suggest. Class discussion will be based on the assignments, student suggested topics, and your experiences at your community-based or change-oriented organizations. Guest speakers will join us throughout the semester. In the past, they have included communications experts, organizers, nonprofit leaders, and lawyers working for change.The final grade will be based approximately on the following three components:(1) Final Project with 40 Volunteer Hour Requirement (60%): While working with a community-based or change-oriented organization, students will develop and complete a final project that will support their organization in their efforts to create change. The final project may consist of one deliverable or a set of deliverables that the organization would find useful in their efforts to advance change. A substantive part of the deliverable(s) will be in writing, but there is no specific page requirement because the length may depend on your organization's needs.The deliverable(s) can take a variety of forms and combinations, and the professor is happy to discuss possibilities and confirm whether any tentative project will meet the course criteria. Some examples of different parts of prior student deliverables are: strategizing with community members and different stakeholders on how to identify and resolve particular issues, crafting the message of a campaign, doing issue research, reviewing and analyzing pending legislation, attending legislative sessions, writing press releases or different types of articles, surveying and interviewing community members and different stakeholders, preparing a report on pertinent issues, creating fact sheets and manuals, planning events, and conducting know your rights presentations for particular communities.Throughout the semester, students will have small assignments (e.g., final project proposal, outline, and first draft) that will be possibly graded on completion, in order to check-in on the progress of the final project. Additionally, students will participate in Peer Feedback Workshops, which involve students presenting an overview of their final project and work with their organization to the class. The Peer Feedback Workshops will be an opportunity for classmates to ask questions, share solutions, and learn from each other regarding the issues that each student is working on during the semester.Students will work with non-lawyers at their community-based or change-oriented organization for a minimum of 40 volunteer hours during the semester. Students will keep track of the hours they have spent assisting their organization and provide a brief, general description of how they spent their time. They will submit their time log with their final project assignments throughout the semester. All time spent toward the creation of the deliverable(s) and working with the organization in any other way (e.g., attending meetings) will count towards fulfilling the students' 40 volunteer hour requirement. The 40 volunteer hour requirement is not a separate component from the final project.(2) Class Attendance and Participation (30%): Every week students will have assignments relating to the course topics. Weekly assignments may include preparing the graded assignments, doing short readings, watching relevant videos, writing down your goals for the semester, or finding a moving message for a campaign. At times, this content will be provided by the guest speakers. Students are expected to come prepared to speak about the assigned materials for the week and to share their experiences working with their organizations.(3) Short Reflection Paper (10%): In addition, students will be assigned one short reflection paper, and students can select from a multitude of prompts to reflect upon their work with their organization relative to different themes examined in this course.If you have questions about any aspect of the course, please contact the professor by email: m-llorente@law.northwestern.edu. The professor is willing and eager to answer any questions about the course, and she is interested in your feedback and suggestions.
School: Law School

Class: 708 Clinic Practice: Center on Wrongful Convictions
ClassOverview: Our clinic focuses on wrongful conviction cases and projects that highlight critical legal issues that arise when innocent individuals are accused or convicted of crimes, especially when they were children or adolescents. Depending on our caseload, our clinic also may include amicus curiae cases, clemency and parole cases, policy reform work, pre-trial criminal defense cases, and the occasional case or project involving someone wrongfully convicted as an adult or someone whose conviction can still be considered wrongful despite some likelihood of factual guilt.Student work may include any of the following: investigating/examining documentary evidence, researching legal issues, drafting motions and briefs, developing demonstrative exhibits, engaging in strategic planning and decision-making, presenting oral argument or questioning witnesses before courts or other tribunals, designing and delivering in-class presentations, interviewing clients and witnesses, or participating in public policy, public education, or reform-related projects.Regardless of the particular projects to which students are assigned, everything that our students do will be aimed toward the development of strategic thinking skills, with an eye towards how the law does - or should - help real people obtain positive and just outcomes.
Instructor: Steven A Drizin| Laura Hepokoski Nirider|

ClassOverview: I'm writing here to tell you about our Fall Semester projects:1.  Working with an Ethiopian NGO and a number of U.S. and Canadian partner NGOs, we'll be continuing advocacy efforts on behalf of an indigenous Guji community that is suffering devastating effects due to toxic contamination (mercury, arsenic, etc.) from the Lega Dembi gold mine.  Details of what we'll do depend on evolving circumstances, but we may write submissions to UN human rights mechanisms, continue our efforts to force the government to make public the results of impact assessments, seek to utilize European laws and regulations with respect to the supply chain obligations of the Swiss refinery that has purchased the gold from this mine, and explore possibilities within the African HR system.2.  We have been asked by two women's rights NGOs in Myanmar to analyze the results of a survey questionnaire on the security situation of women in Myanmar following the military coup, to write a report based on these results, and to engage in international advocacy using the report.  Please understand that this project may be canceled or delayed if either the security situation or the pandemic make it impossible for our NGO partners to proceed at this time; I am hopeful, though, that we will be able to move forward on this.3.  Working with the newly-founded Geneva-based International Platform for Corporate Liability, we will continue work begun last year to research whether grounds exist to hold corporate actors in the gold and diamond sectors criminally liable for complicity in crimes against humanity in the Central African Republic.4. With luck, we may be able to resume clinic travel this fall.  I am hopeful that some of us will be able to attend the UN Forum on Business & HR in November, and there is a small possibility we may be able to return to Addis Ababa to continue our work with our colleagues in Ethiopia.  Of course, this will be dependent on the pandemic situation.5.  We may add another project - perhaps in collaboration with a legal clinic in either Arequipa, Peru, or Tbilisi, Georgia, or in collaboration with an LGBTQ+ NGO in Sri Lanka that my clinic has worked with in the past.6. Do you have an idea of a HR project you would really like to work on?  I am always open to student suggestions for projects that are suitable for this clinic, though whether we can proceed with an idea this coming semester depends on time demands of all projects.
School: Law School

ClassOverview: Students will represent individuals and organizations in cutting-edge civil rights suits at both the trial and appellate level. Trial case assignments are likely to include conducting discovery and trial preparation in wrongful conviction damages cases; investigating claims and drafting complaints in parole reform litigation, challenges to police surveillance, and excessive use of force by law enforcement; and conducting discovery and preparing for trial in prison condition suits.  Appellate assignments are likely to include challenging the Prison Litigation Reform Act (PLRA), the application of qualified immunity, conditions of confinement, excessive force, and religious deprivations behind prison and jail walls, as well as unconstitutional policing.

ClassOverview: In the fall semester of 2021, Copyright will start by talking about the development of the U.S. copyright statute over the centuries. For roughly the first two-thirds the course, we'll talk about the basics: the requirements for copyright validity; limitations on copyright protection; the elements of copyright infringement; the various types of copyright infringement; defenses to infringement; and remedies. For the remaining third of the course, we'll talk about more specialized topics such as formalities, moral rights, music industry regulation, and software copyright. We will use a free casebook that is available for free download online. We will do in-class exercises regularly.

ClassOverview: Design Thinking and Communication (DTC) is Segal's two-quarter, foundational design course, serving students from all engineering majors.In DTC's first quarter, most projects involve solving problems for people with special needs, such as rehabilitation. In the second quarter, projects address a variety of problems like healthcare, industry, and education.DTC is team-taught by faculty from McCormick and Northwestern's Writing Program. The course is listed under Design and English; as you study design, you also fulfill McCormick's writing requirement.

ClassOverview: Design Thinking and Doing is a dynamic, project-based introduction to design, structured as a hands-on studio course. Students will learn key methods of design innovation and will work in teams to apply those methods, learning how to uncover opportunities, explore ideas, prototype solutions, and interact with users.  In addition to regular class time, the course will offer a series of workshops to help students develop specific design skills which suit the interests and needs of the class.  Students will be required to participate in at least one workshop but may engage in as many as desired. At the end of the quarter, students will present their design concepts, showcasing prototypes in engaging and thoughtful ways.
Instructor: John Christopher Anderson| Kimberly S Hahn|
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: Sketching is intended to increase one's skills in a basic but essential form of communication; it's the medium used by all for preliminary ideation. In this course you will understand basic rules and develop your skills in a design studio setting.
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: Solid modeling covers the principles of creating three dimensional shapes through two dimensional sketches, then combining individual parts into assemblies. Students will review CAD modeling theory and learn the various advantages and disadvantages of modeling objects using different approaches for creating identical features. A balance between lecture and hands-on software use will allow you to familiarize yourself with Solidworks.
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: This is a project-based design course focusing upon ensuring that products meet the needs of their users. The course introduces observational methods, brainstorming, rapid prototyping, user testing, business models, and the social, marketing, and engineering concerns that impinge upon products.Students will do weekly project assignments aimed at illustrating the concepts discussed in class and readings. Students will also work in teams to plan, design and develop a product to the prototype stage.
MeetingInfo: Ford Eng Design Cntr G-201: Mon, 6:00PM - 8:50PM
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: Contact the department for further information
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: Design for fabrication is an introduction to manufacturing processes including casting, injection molding, additive manufacturing, extrusion, machining, joining, and forming, using materials commonly found in modern consumer and industrial products. Online lectures will be paired with weekly, hands-on labs where students will be able to apply theory of manufacturing processes to the design of parts and process tooling for various fabrication methods. Focus will be placed on the exploration of part design and process parameters, to obtain an optimal outcome for a given manufacturing process. Students will become proficient in both the advantages and limitations of various fabrication methods, in order to better prepare them for the design of a component and implementation into a production line.Students will fabricate multiple small products during the course, using lab sessions to create components by different manufacturing methods. Weekly homework will involve studies of various manufacturing methods, optimization and/or choice of fabrication method for a given part, and practice & preparation for in-lab manufacturing.
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: In this capstone course, required for students pursuing a design certificate, you will create a portfolio that showcases your engineering work and furthers a personal career goal, such as obtaining a job or getting into a graduate program.The portfolio itself is a design project that presents your story in a physical form. As you develop prototypes and obtain feedback on your portfolio design, you will gain insight into engineering as a profession and yourself as an engineer.
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: This course is part of a 2-quarter sequence.In this service design studio students will explore a human centered approach to the design of services. Students will explore and apply design thinking to a client sponsored project and synthesize both user and client needs to the design of tangible consumer touch-points. This may include experiences plans, digital interface designs, communication models, organizational designs, systems and/or brand tonality deliverables. Coursework will be workshop based with a majority of team assignments supported by specific individual responsibilities.
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: Course descriptionThis is the first quarter of a two-quarter, learn-by-doing class in which student teams participate in an interdisciplinary design project. The course has a dual focus on (1) the engineering and social science elements of design and (2) effective communication as a professional skill. The second quarter focuses on project implementation and ongoing professional communication.In the DSGN 384-1,2 course sequence, students work in teams on interdisciplinary projects in a learn-by-doing format. Each team works on one project across both quarters, for 20 weeks. The first quarter emphasizes project research, iterative concept development and prototyping, and professional communication, and it includes lectures on advanced topics in design. The quarter culminates in a conceptual design and a design review. The second quarter focuses on project implementation supported by iterative prototyping, testing, and analysis, as well as continued professional communication. The projects focus on the technical side of design. While users are still a consideration, they are not the primary focus as in the DTC or DTD courses. Students are expected to apply the discipline-specific knowledge from their upper-level courses.
MeetingInfo: Ford Eng Design Cntr G-205: Tues, Thurs, 3:30PM - 5:20PM
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science

ClassOverview: In this new course, we'll create art as a means to draw attention to current challenges combating racism. There will be bi-weekly prompts to inspire you, centered on the themes of Tema Okun's work. You'll have access to Ford Building fabrication facilities, ranging from the shop to the mechatronics lab to the Corner Makery.This hands-on, studio-based class is open to all undergraduate and graduate students interested in creating meaningful, well-considered artifacts; prior making experience advised, or come ready to invest significant time and learn quickly.This course is envisioned for in-person learning only at this time, though we will continue to assess that as time goes on.Enrollment is limited to sixteen students and we seek to create a diverse classroom in terms of backgrounds and majors. Interested? Send a note to pam@northwestern.edu and birdwell@northwestern.edu explaining a bit about you and what intrigues you about the class. Questions? Ask!A way to think about this course is as a studio-supported independent study.  If you've got some bold thoughts about how the world could be better and different, and want to give form to those thoughts, this could be a great class for you!
Instructor: Jay Alexander Birdwell| Pamela A. Forgianni Daniels|

ClassOverview: Prerequisites: An understanding of the fundamentals of machine learning and image processing. Students will be expected to read papers that utilize advanced machine learning and image processing techniques. Familiarity with one of the major machine-learning software frameworks is required to complete the class project.This seminar course will introduce engineering and computer science students to applications of machine learning in biomedical imaging, sensor, and genomic data. Lectures will orient students to application domains and issues in data, algorithm design, and validation and will provide background for paper discussions in areas including radiology, pathology, and critical care. A course project provides hands-on experience designing and validating machine learning models with real-world data.
School: McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science
Section: 76: Machine Learning for Medical Images and Signals - Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
